Entries.default: "Captain, a word?" Tekhu inclines his head and touches his forehead spot.
"When I joined the guild, I was a fish in a dream." Tekhu looks at the ground between his feet.
"Mairu lied to you. To everyone. You owe the guild nothing."
"Nothing? Would I still be Tekhu without the gifts and encouragement this place lavished upon me?" Tekhu looks from the floor to the ceiling, his frown a constant fixture.
"I do not want to tarry in this house of regret a moment longer."
"My thoughts will be clearer in time. You are kind to listen, I say."
"You will get through this. Stand by your faith in the guild."
"Ekera, even if this faith was a lie?"
"The guild might need a new way forward if it hopes to endure."
"If the guild cannot depend on its own teachings, then difficult times lie ahead of us all."
"The guild should have trusted in the strength of its watershapers."
"Ekera. No matter how many warships sailed against us, the Huana should have relied on each other first."

"Now I see the guild only for what it has become - ekera, a perversion of the oldest Huana art."

He grimaces and looks away.
"Watershapers were the keepers of our oldest covenant, protectors of history. Heroes, I say."
